channel.title: Side by side servers, how do you do it?
channel.description: How would I run two servers on the same machine? The error I'm getting is: "[java] /root/Servers/LinServer/build.xml:29: java.io.IOException: Cannot run program "/usr/lib/jvm/java-6-openjdk/jre/bin/java": java.io.IOException: error=12, Cannot allocate memory", which I believe we can safely assume is because Java is already in use. Now, why does this happen? I can run two instances of Python and two RSC clients so why can I not run two servers? They are on different ports ;).

item.title: Side by side servers, how do you do it?
item.dc:creator: @darscape darscape
item.description:
@darscape wrote:

Welcome to java programs on linux. For some reason, Windows handles java in RAM far better and does not need to use anywhere as much.

Your choices are: play around with the <jvmarg value="-Xmx512m" /> until it has just enough to fit both servers in RAM without having them crash once having run out of allocated memory, have Windows Server 2003 or
2007 installed and operate through remote desktop with the ability to use your RAM in the most optimal way, or you can add additional gigs of RAM. Once your listening server is running, you just have to worry about the world servers connecting to it locally. Use different ports for each world server or if you have several static IP addresses on your server, bind each world server to a seperate IP and keep using the default port.

Read full topic
item.source: Side by side servers, how do you do it?

item.title: Side by side servers, how do you do it?

item.description:

I have 2210MiB in use with the server running and 319MiB in use without the server…How can this be fixed?

item.description:

[quote=“Kryptix, post:1, topic:320911”][quote author=adu link=topic=417321.msg3068639#msg3068639 date=1261377472]
“Cannot allocate memory”
[/quote][/quote]

I’m aware it says that, I purchased another IP was that the wrong choice? How can I help it allocate the memory?

item.title: Side by side servers, how do you do it?
item.dc:creator: @inTouch inTouch
item.description:
@inTouch wrote:

Simply use another port, so if one server uses 43594, the other one should use something else, e.g. 43595. :rolleyes:

Read full topic

lolol you simply set up 2 ips for that machine and change one of the world and/or ls configs to that ip :\ i offered to help the fellow.
